section.title: Usage information
section.p: The data element is primarily intended for use with specialization. The ability to nest data within itself allows the creation of complex metadata structures. Because it is generally available in both block and inline contexts, data allows the specification of properties for most element types.

A metadata property specified using data ordinarily applies to the container of that data element. In the content model for the prolog and metadata elements, the property applies to the topic as a whole. In the topicmeta element, the property applies to the referenced topic. The data-about element can be used to identify the subject of the property with an explicit reference.
section.note: Processors by default will not render the content of the data element. The data element should be used only for properties and not to embed text for formatting as part of the flow of the topic body. For example, it would be possible to specialize data to create a special kind of paragraph where p is not allowed; however, when the content is shared, other tools or processors will ignore the specialized data element.

section.title: Processing expectations
section.p: Default processing SHOULD treat a data element as an unknown kind of metadata and not render its content.
Processors that recognize a particular data element can make use of that data as appropriate. For example, a specialized data element could be used to alter the rendering of related content.

fig.title: Using the name attribute on unspecialized data elements
fig.p: In the following code sample, the data element is used to provide information about a code sample, allowing rendering tools that recognize this metadata to automatically apply highlighting in the code.

fig.title: Nesting data elements for complex metadata
fig.p: In the following code sample, nested data elements provide complex inventory metadata for a part described in the topic.
fig.codeblock: <topic id="sample"> <title>How to purchase SuperWidgets from BigWarehouse</title> <prolog> <data name="inventory"> <data name="aisle" value="4"/> <data name="bin" value="13"/> <data name="restock" value="weekly"/> </data> </prolog> <body> <!-- ... --> </body> </topic>

fig.title: Specializing data for structured metadata
fig.p: In the following code sample, which uses elements taken from DITA 1.3, the data element is specialized to create the elements change-item, change-completed, and change-summary. These elements each provide a default for name inside the grammar files, so that processors can work with the data without authors having to specify the attribute.
fig.codeblock: <topic id="data"> <title><xmlelement>data</xmlelement></title> <shortdesc><!-- ... --></shortdesc> <prolog> <change-historylist> <change-item> <change-completed>2017-08-20</change-completed> <change-summary>Refactored topic to use new template</change-summary> </change-item> <change-item> <change-completed>2018-06-06</change-completed> <change-summary>Created new examples</change-summary> </change-item> </change-historylist> </prolog> <body> <!-- ... --> </body> </topic>
